column1: The origins of Betar are likely in the Iron Age Kingdom of Judea. It is not mentioned in the canonical Hebrew Bible
column2: but is added in the Septuagint as one of the cities of the Tribe of Judah.The location produced archaeological finds of pottery beginning from 8th century BCE and until late period of the Kingdom of Judah and again from early Roman period. In the early second century the town was a major stronghold and urban center in the Bethlehem area.

column1: The city was the stronghold of Bar Kokhba
column2: the leader of the Jewish Revolt against Roman occupation and took place in the days of Emperor Hadrian. After losing many of their strongholds
column3: Bar Kokhba and the remnants of his army withdrew to the fortress of Betar
column4: which subsequently came under siege in the summer of 135. Based on an inscription found there
column5: the Legio V Macedonica and Legio XI Claudia have taken part in the siege. A stone inscription bearing Latin characters and discovered near the city shows that the Fifth Macedonian Legion and the Eleventh Claudian Legion took part in the siege.
